Playing a cultured but chilling character within the show’s layered reality, Boehmer gave the antagonists an unsettling polish that contrasted with the chaos of the battle sequences and underscored the moral stakes of the story.

J. Paul Boehmer.header: Recurring Appearances on Star Trek: Enterprise
J. Paul Boehmer.text: Boehmer returned to Star Trek again in Star Trek: Enterprise, where he took on multiple roles. He played the augmented Human scientist in “Borderland,” the Romulan drone-ship commander in “Babel One,” “United,” and “The Aenar,” and other heavily made-up characters who required him to work through prosthetics and costuming. These performances relied on his ability to suggest intelligence, ruthlessness, or calculation through voice and posture as much as facial expression, reinforcing his reputation as one of the franchise’s go-to character actors.

Outside of on-camera roles, Boehmer has developed a substantial career as a voice actor, particularly in audiobooks and audio drama. He has narrated or contributed to recordings ranging from genre fiction to literary works, using his classical training to differentiate characters and sustain long-form narration. His vocal control and clear diction make him well suited to audio formats where the entire burden of storytelling rests on sound rather than visuals.

J. Paul Boehmer.header: Television Guest Spots Beyond Star Trek
J. Paul Boehmer.text: In addition to his Star Trek work, Boehmer has appeared as a guest star on other television series, typically in single-episode or short recurring parts. He has taken roles in procedural dramas and genre shows where he often plays professionals—doctors, officers, investigators, or specialists—whose scenes help set up or resolve key plot points. These appearances reflect the way casting directors have come to rely on him as a precise, understated character actor who can quickly inhabit a role and support the ensemble.

Boehmer has extended his voice work into video games and interactive projects, contributing performances to titles that require strong characterization within limited lines and branching story paths. Whether voicing military personnel, scientists, or morally ambiguous figures, he brings the same clarity and attention to detail that mark his audiobook and television work, helping to elevate narrative-driven games that depend heavily on believable vocal performances.

Even as film and television have expanded his audience, Boehmer has maintained ties to the stage and to audio. He has continued to perform in theatre productions when schedules permit and has remained active as a narrator, reflecting a career that deliberately balances screen visibility with the artistic satisfaction of live performance and literary adaptation. This mix keeps his craft grounded in the fundamentals of acting while allowing him to participate in a wide array of media.

For the general public, J. Paul Boehmer may be a familiar face or voice from scattered film roles, television guest spots, and audiobook covers; for Star Trek fans he is part of the franchise’s unofficial repertory company of actors who return again and again in new guises. His work across Deep Space Nine, Voyager, and Enterprise—often under heavy makeup, portraying very different species and personalities—has made him a respected figure in science-fiction circles and a quiet but enduring contributor to the larger Star Trek tapestry.

Michael Krawic.header: American Character Actor of Stage and Screen
Michael Krawic.text: Michael A. Krawic (born 12 April 1952) is an American character actor whose career spans theatre, film, television, and voice work. Known to genre fans for his appearances across several Star Trek series, he has also built a résumé that includes studio features, independent films, network dramas, and animated projects.

Krawic trained formally as an actor, earning an MFA from Chicago’s Goodman School of Drama at DePaul University (now The Theatre School). He began working professionally in 1982 and quickly established himself on stage, ultimately performing in more than seventy-five productions while developing the vocal and physical technique that would underpin his later screen work.

On stage, Krawic has appeared in a wide range of classical and contemporary plays, moving through regional and repertory companies as well as urban theatre scenes. His roles have included complex dramas, comedies, and character pieces, giving him opportunities to explore psychologically layered parts and ensemble work that demanded precision and consistency from performance to performance.

Michael Krawic.header: Early Screen Roles and Television Guest Spots
Michael Krawic.text: By the 1990s, Krawic was working regularly in film and television. Early screen credits included TV movies such as Broken Promises: Taking Emily Back and supporting parts in features like First Kid, along with guest appearances on series including 7th Heaven, Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman, and Walker, Texas Ranger. These roles often cast him as professionals—lawyers, officials, or specialists—who added texture to episodic stories.

Michael Krawic.header: Feature Films from Thrillers to Horror
Michael Krawic.text: Krawic’s film work has spanned crime drama, action, and horror. He appeared in the noir-inflected Mulholland Falls, the martial-arts sequel Bloodsport 4: The Dark Kumite, and the feature adaptation of The X-Files, before taking roles in John Carpenter’s Ghosts of Mars and the comedy Legally Blonde 2: Red, White & Blonde. Later, he co-starred in Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension, playing Father Todd in the final entry of the found-footage horror franchise.

Michael Krawic.header: Star Trek: Deep Space Nine – William Patrick Samuels
Michael Krawic.text: Krawic entered the Star Trek universe on Star Trek: Deep Space Nine as William Patrick Samuels in the second-season episode “The Maquis, Part I.” The character appears in a political thriller storyline involving Starfleet, Cardassians, and the Maquis resistance, and Krawic’s performance underscored the tensions and moral ambiguity surrounding Federation citizens living on the Cardassian border.

Michael Krawic.header: Star Trek: Voyager and Enterprise – Rahmin and Stron
Michael Krawic.text: He returned to the franchise in Star Trek: Voyager as Rahmin in the episode “Day of Honor,” interacting with B’Elanna Torres during a crisis that tests Klingon tradition and personal resilience. On Star Trek: Enterprise he appeared as the Vulcan engineer Stron in “Carbon Creek,” the period-set story about an earlier Vulcan visit to Earth. Playing very different aliens under makeup, Krawic helped flesh out corners of Star Trek’s 24th- and 22nd-century continuity.

Beyond Star Trek, Krawic has accumulated numerous television credits in contemporary drama and genre television. He has appeared on series such as CSI and Angel, and later turned up on Showtime’s Shameless, shifting comfortably between procedural storytelling, supernatural drama, and grounded, working-class comedy. These guest and co-starring roles continued the pattern of casting him as grounded, believable figures inside heightened narratives.

Michael Krawic.header: Voice Acting in Legends of Oz
Michael Krawic.text: Krawic has also worked in animation and voice performance. Notably, he voiced Uncle Henry in the 2014 animated feature Legends of Oz: Dorothy’s Return, a continuation of the Wizard of Oz story featuring an ensemble voice cast. The project highlighted his ability to convey character through voice alone, a skill built on years of stage and microphone work.

Michael Krawic.header: Later Film Projects and Genre Work
Michael Krawic.text: In the 2010s he continued to appear in film projects, including roles in The Last Tour and Lookin Up, while maintaining a presence at film-festival and genre-fan events. His work in horror and science fiction, alongside more grounded dramas, has made him a familiar face to viewers who follow independent features and late-night cable programming as much as mainstream theatrical releases.

Michael Krawic.header: Balancing Stage, Screen, and New Media
Michael Krawic.text: Throughout his career, Krawic has balanced stage and screen work with appearances at conventions and participation in new media or low-budget projects, reflecting a willingness to explore different storytelling formats. That mix has allowed him to maintain an active career, continuing to add new credits while drawing on the discipline and craft developed in his early theatre years.

Michael Krawic’s legacy is that of a dedicated working actor: a performer with deep theatrical training who has quietly contributed to dozens of films and television shows while taking on memorable roles in beloved franchises like Star Trek. Whether playing a conflicted border-world human, an alien engineer, a priest confronting the supernatural, or a supporting figure in a legal or crime drama, he brings professionalism and specificity that help larger stories feel real.

Bruce Gray.header: Puerto Rican–Born Canadian Screen and Stage Actor
Bruce Gray.text: Bruce Gray (born Robert Bruce Gray, September 7, 1936 – December 13, 2017) was a Puerto Rican-born Canadian actor whose career spanned more than five decades. Working in Canada and the United States, he became a familiar presence in film, television, and theatre, equally at home in prestige drama, daytime serials, genre cinema, and science fiction franchises.

Bruce Gray.header: Early Life, Education, and Move to Canada
Bruce Gray.text: Gray was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, to Canadian parents and moved to Toronto in 1949. He attended Humberside Collegiate Institute and later the University of Toronto, where he earned a master’s degree in psychology. While at university he became active in student theatre and joined the Phi Delta Theta fraternity, discovering that performing on stage appealed to him more than an academic or clinical career.

Bruce Gray.header: Entering the Profession and Building a Résumé
Bruce Gray.text: After a small screen role in the 1966 film "Adulterous Affair," Gray gradually shifted from academic work toward acting full time. Through the 1970s and 1980s he built a résumé that mixed Canadian and American projects, appearing in television movies, guest roles on series, and stage productions. His grounded, intelligent screen presence led to recurring work in soaps and serial dramas, while his theatrical background kept him in demand on stage.

Bruce Gray.header: Daytime Serials and Early Television Visibility
Bruce Gray.text: Gray became a recognizable face on daytime television with roles on serials such as "All My Children," "The Edge of Night," and "The Young and the Restless." Playing professionals, family patriarchs, and authority figures, he brought a measured, believable style to a medium that often relied on heightened emotion. These shows introduced him to a wide audience and established him as a dependable ensemble player in long-running series.

Bruce Gray.header: Traders and a Signature Canadian Role
Bruce Gray.text: In the mid-1990s Gray took on one of his defining roles as investment banker Adam Cunningham on the Canadian drama "Traders." Across four seasons he portrayed a sharp, demanding senior executive navigating the high-stakes world of Bay Street finance. The series became a critical and popular success in Canada, and Gray’s performance as Cunningham—at once formidable, vulnerable, and often dryly witty—earned him a Gemini Award and solidified his status as a major figure in Canadian television drama.

Bruce Gray.header: Film Work from Starship Troopers to My Big Fat Greek Wedding
Bruce Gray.text: Gray’s film career included a wide range of supporting roles. He played Sky Marshal Dienes, the political leader of humanity, in the satirical science-fiction film "Starship Troopers"; Colonel Thomas H. Maguire in "Cube 2: Hypercube"; and Rodney Miller, the reserved father of the groom, in the international hit "My Big Fat Greek Wedding." He also appeared in titles such as "Dragnet," "For the Boys," "My Family," "Up Close & Personal," "S.W.A.T.," and "Monster-in-Law," often cast as executives, officials, or fathers whose reactions help anchor larger stories.

Bruce Gray.header: Prestige Drama and Recurring Television Roles
Bruce Gray.text: Beyond soaps and Traders, Gray maintained a steady presence in film and television drama. He had recurring work as Judge J.E. Reilly on the daytime serial "Passions" and appeared as the ghost of Joe Dubois’s father on the supernatural drama "Medium." He played wealthy pickle magnate George Schickel on "Queer as Folk," bringing warmth and pathos to the role of a closeted older man, and turned up in series such as "NCIS," "Boston Legal," and "Big Love," where he was frequently cast as professionals or authority figures facing moral or personal challenges.

Gray developed a strong foothold in science fiction and genre television. In addition to "Starship Troopers" and "Cube 2," he appeared on "Babylon 5" as the interrogator who questions Captain John Sheridan in the intense episode "Intersections in Real Time." His ability to convey controlled menace, political calculation, or institutional pressure made him a natural fit for genre stories that blend speculative concepts with psychological drama.

Bruce Gray.header: Star Trek: Admiral Chekote and Surak
Bruce Gray.text: Within the Star Trek franchise, Gray is best known for multiple roles. He played Vice Admiral (later Admiral) Chekote in Star Trek: The Next Generation’s "Gambit, Part I" and Deep Space Nine’s "The Circle," portraying a senior Starfleet officer navigating political crisis. Years later he returned to the franchise on Star Trek: Enterprise as the Vulcan philosopher Surak in the fourth-season episode "Awakening." Under subtle prosthetic makeup he gave Surak a calm, iconic presence, embodying the rational, disciplined ideals that underpin Vulcan culture.

Across his career Gray moved fluidly between mediums and genres. He could be found in historical miniseries, TV movies about political scandals or military incidents, legal and medical dramas, and light comedies. He was equally convincing as a senator, corporate leader, judge, military officer, or quietly exasperated parent, and casting directors often relied on him to give exposition-heavy or structurally important scenes a sense of authenticity and emotional weight.

Even in the later stages of his career Gray continued to work regularly, taking roles in series, films, and stage projects while also directing theatre and occasionally appearing in advertising campaigns—most memorably as the face of a tongue-in-cheek anti-Amsterdam organization in commercials for Amstel beer. He remained active into his eighties, reflecting both his professionalism and his enduring appeal to producers on both sides of the border.

Bruce Gray died of cancer in Los Angeles on December 13, 2017, at the age of 81. To Canadian audiences he is fondly remembered as Adam Cunningham of "Traders"; to filmgoers he is the reserved father in "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" or the imposing Sky Marshal in "Starship Troopers"; to Star Trek and science-fiction fans he is Admiral Chekote, Surak, and the relentless interrogator on "Babylon 5." Taken together, his work illustrates the impact a versatile, committed character actor can have across multiple genres and generations of screen storytelling.
